de.upb.t2t.control

Class AbstractResourceProvider

  • java.lang.Object
    • de.upb.t2t.control.AbstractResourceProvider
  • Direct Known Subclasses:
    ConfigProvider, CSSProvider, FXMLProvider, ImageProvider

    public abstract class AbstractResourceProvider
extends java.lang.Object

    A convenience class whose implementations only need to override the getInfix() function. Any sub-class file should be added into a folder containing resources the application may wish to use. This approach may seem somewhat clumsy at first sight. However, since the project obeys to the Gluon conventions, resource files need to be located for example in the src/main/resources folder. Inconveniently, said folder structure changes once the application has been packed into a .jar file. This class will automatically take care of both use cases.

    Important: Please note that when running the application from inside eclipse (or potentially any other IDE), the folder containing the .class files is where instances of this class will point to. This should normally be the bin directory and not its src counterpart. Therefore, changes made by the application will not be adapted in the src files.

    Author:
    Michel May (michel-may@gmx.de)
    See Also:
    getResourceAsStream(String), getResourceAsURL(String), getResourceAsFile(String)

    • Method Detail

      • executedFromJar

        private static boolean executedFromJar(java.io.File applicationRoot)
        A convenience function checking whether or not the application is being launched from within a .jar file.
        Parameters:
        applicationRoot - the application's root file/directory.
        Returns:
        true if the paramter is a .jar file; false otherwise.

      • getInfix

        protected abstract java.lang.String getInfix()
        Returns the path relative to the executed .jar to the current folder it should point to. This path is irrelevant if the application is running from inside an IDE.
        Returns:
        the path to the resource folde relative to the application's .jar file.

      • getResourceAsStream

        public java.io.InputStream getResourceAsStream(java.lang.String filename)
                                        throws java.net.URISyntaxException,
                                               java.io.FileNotFoundException
        When an a Java programme is compiled into a .jar file, every resource it may require that has also been packed into said file will become read-only. Therefore, files that need to be modified at runtime should placed outside the .jar and accessed via this function.
        Parameters:
        filename - the name of the file to obtain.
        Returns:
        the given file as an InputStream.
        Throws:
        java.net.URISyntaxException - if getApplicationRoot() throws one.
        java.io.FileNotFoundException - if FileInputStream.FileInputStream(String) throws one.

      • getResourceAsURL

        public java.net.URL getResourceAsURL(java.lang.String filename)
                              throws java.net.URISyntaxException,
                                     java.net.MalformedURLException
        When an a Java programme is compiled into a .jar file, every resource it may require that has also been packed into said file will become read-only. Therefore, files that need to be modified at runtime should placed outside the .jar and accessed via this function.
        Parameters:
        filename - the name of the file to obtain.
        Returns:
        the given file as a URL.
        Throws:
        java.net.URISyntaxException - if getApplicationRoot() or URL.toURI() throw one.
        java.net.MalformedURLException - if URI.toURL() throws one.

        When an a Java programme is compiled into a .jar file, every resource it may require that has also been packed into said file will become read-only. Therefore, files that need to be modified at runtime should placed outside the .jar and accessed via this function.

        Returns:
